course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: A team runs a long cycle with no check until the end. What is the risk?
options: Learning is delayed; reality corrects plans too late when changes are expensive
They will work harder and produce better results without feedback or validation
It is cheaper to avoid interim checks and focus only on final delivery
No significant risk in this case; long cycles without feedback are always better

questions.question: A team launches a feature, waits 3 months, then checks if users like it. What is missing compared to a proper feedback loop?
options: A feedback loop gets real-world signal quickly to adjust the next move, not after months
Sending a survey at the end without interim checks or adjustments
Asking for approval without testing actual outcomes or usage
Reporting status only without gathering signal from real users

questions.question: How do you shorten the time between action and signal?
options: Define the next feedback moment: when and how you will get signal; move it earlier if possible
Work faster to complete everything sooner without interim checks
Send more emails to stakeholders without gathering actual user feedback
Meet more often to discuss progress without testing with real users

questions.question: Ignoring feedback that contradicts the plan can lead to:
options: Investing in a wrong direction while evidence says otherwise
Stronger commitment
Faster execution
No significant downside in practice

questions.question: Measuring only what confirms the plan is risky because:
options: You miss disconfirming signal and update too late
You save time
You please stakeholders
It has no effect on outcomes or learning

questions.question: For one active initiative, what should you define?
options: The next feedback moment: when and how you will get signal to adjust course
The final deadline only without interim checkpoints or feedback loops
The full list of tasks without identifying when to check progress or gather signal
Who is responsible only without defining how to measure success or get feedback

questions.question: Why is "reality is your best mentor" important?
options: Reality corrects plans; fast loops reduce the cost of being wrong and enable learning
Reality is always right so plans are unnecessary and should be avoided
Plans are useless and should be replaced entirely by reacting to reality
It is optional and not necessary for successful project delivery
